item.title: Mac minis are the new ASIC miners — 57 replies — 228.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Mac minis are the new ASIC miners

Open thread • Replies: 57 • Updated: 2026-02-25 15:12 UTC

OP

Mac minis are like the ASIC miners except they do actual work instead of mining bitcoin for no reason.

Early replies (first 3)

61893585
>>61893434
What are people even doing with their 50 mac mini AI agents?

61893611
>>61893585
Its like a team of 50 indians

61893612
>>61893611
Just imagine the sound of 50 echoing good morning sirs

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61895757
>>61895191
Glorified googling program.

I’ve tried to use AI to diagnose some tricky health issues I’ve had and while it did help at first, I’m pretty sure it eventually tried to kill me.

61895762
>>61895732
If it was 'the same price' people would choose the faster option, aka notMac. The problem with the cheap option here being - again - you can cool GPUs and they are somewhat designed to be ran at high temps for extended periods. Mac Minis weren't and aren't. And these retards are going to fry their Mactrash, abusing them 24/7 as retarded AI agents.

61895788
you really don't need a mac mini, old Lenovo Thinkcenters work perfectly fine and you get get a used one with 32GB of ram and 2 TB of disk space for like $200-300

I have been using a few with Unbuntu installed to run a bunch of agents on an isolated Vlan at home. (These things are honestly security risks, don't give them access to your home network or personal info)

61895820
>>61895757
chatgpt is useless now, its a glorified yes man. You can actually trick it into giving horrific advice. Which puts it at the level of a 32 year old life coach, nothing more. Gemini is a good tool if you can get a local unit to run, great for helping map and document trades. But nothing more than that, if you really needed something to bounce ideas off of it isn't that. But that is all you can expect out of it, a really good calculator. It's when people expect it to be a thinking breathing human is when problems arise

61895868
>>61895788
And what model can you on 32gb ram? Thinkcentres dont have dedicated gpu do they?

61895888
>>61895868
no one is running the actual model locally, this is for running the agent and all its tools, most people are running API calls off Openrouter

61895922
>>61895888
These ARE running local models, that's the entire point of using MacMinis and unified RAM. Whether the Minis will survive the experience, is another issue entirely.

61896004
>>61895757
Interesting.
Mine kept saying im trans. Kek!
> sadface.jpg

61896011
>>61894156
>>give the mac mini all of my personal info, financial data, passwords, internet browsing history etc.
It's a personal computer. It already has all of those things.

61896031
>>61895820
Yes that’s pretty much it. Although it did help me diagnose leaky gut issues and initially helped with some supplements, but then it started telling me to basically OD on magnesium and electrolytes.

61896090
>>61894238
Rent it to people that are scared of running it locally or too stupid to figure it out.
Stuff like this https://seafloor.bot/

61896126
Basically in the future everyone will have their own personal agentic AI, and these people are hosting them while its still hard to get it set up.
This isnt a sustainable business model tho, because its only a matter of time before soke big company like google starts doing it with infinitely more success because they actually have all the data from everyone, so the AI assistant will come out of factory already knowing you better than you know yourself.
But it will be profitable probably for a 1 or 2. I dont see this stuff getting released by a big company before its tested enough to ensure most of the nightmarish stories being reported about openclaw have a close to 0% chance of happening.

61896174
>>61893434
>they do actual work
how much money has your agent made?

61896193
>>61895922
No they aren't. They're just a bunch of iToddlers who can't into Raspberry Pi or Linux.

61896922
>>61896126
>knowing you better than you know yourself
it's actually pretty hard to personalize large language models, so dont expect the same behaviour as you have from your tiktok or youtube algorithm

61896954
this is pure retardium. the minis are not running shit. they can't run any models, and anyways open models are not worth running, they're dumb as rocks
openclaw uses api to run, claude because it's the only one that can do shit. the fattest claude (the only able one) can burn hundreds of $$$ per day. and you don't need a mac mini for it. you can just run it on the cloud or in a virtual machine. it's really lean on resources - you just need to pay a lot of money for the api
dumb. all of it is just dumb

61896995
>>61895757
Must be a canadian llm, MAID GPT.

61897015
>>61896193
It's the same software. If you can't into linux then you definitely can't into macos. Both start up into a first class GUI and both require you to drop to the command line to install LLM shit because that's how the software works. Ollama front ends not withstanding.
Hell, raspi clusters are easy mode because it far easier to find a prebaked recipe you can copy/paste to get it all running whereas mac users have to deal with retards hardcoding paths and cuda bullshit into their workflows.
That said there is some retardation going on with the mac buying. Macs are the sane choice because they are the absolute cheapest way to get more than 64GB with GPU access to that pool. Your 128GB of DDR5 and a xeon doesn't compare. Buying a joblot of 16GB mac minis is defeating the purpose though.

61897157
>>61895163
correct

>>61895732
wrong. AMD GPUs out on price to performance ratios for AI as long as you have enough IQ to configure rocm kernel

61897160
>>61897157
*AMD GPUs win out

61898771
>>61897157
I'll believe it when I see it. A PC with enough VRAM on the GPU to beat mac, I don't think it works. Plus that pc has to do offloading.

61899637
>>61893699
Computer engineer here:
The thing that makes the M chips a game-changer is that they use AI to accelerate AI workloads. The result? AI squared. This has been the holy grail of the mac mini’s eye-watering efficiency. I guarantee you that in five years, every AI PC on the market will use AI to accelerate its AI accelerator for AI. AI cubed, if you will.

61899711
>>61893434
who else running stealth asics hidden in the attic at their office? place is full of dumb cunts that wouldn't even find it if i told them it was there

61899788
>>61898771
>>61895922
Nonsense. Mac unified memory is slow because it has low memory bandwidth which is very important for fast inference.
Offloading is not a needed when you have real GPUs with 96-256GB memory capacity.

Minis are good for single core tasks (python/js) and ARM is power efficient so I guess it's suited for API agents. Local LLMs are worse for most tasks anyway.

61899789
>>61896192
This has been the case for both crypto and AI, but at least the latter is useful for most people.

61899866
>>61895191
i use a local LLM to write passable warhammer fantasy stories for me

61899869
>>61899637
e = mc^2 + AI

61900078
>>61899788
>Local LLMs are worse for most tasks anyway.
What are they good for?

61900675
>>61895163
Its almost entirely about ram costs. A single mac studio with 512 gb of unified memory can run a monster of a local AI set up. Hundreds of billions of parameters. To build a PC with 512 gb of vram is basically impossible, so you are stuck using less efficient 512gb ddr5 + CPU set ups for twice the price and half the performance. Mac studio/mini is the ideal locally hosted AI machine by a wide margin, both price and performance wise.

61894003
>>61893298

>Tried selling my silver today
First mistake.

>spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area
Have you tried not living in Alaska?
>pawn broker says they only pay 90% of spot price, including a 12% processing fee
So they pay 2% over spot...Nice
>IRS also collects 28% in taxes
Common misconception that precious metals are taxed at 28%. The reality is that you owe tax according to your income bracket which means that if you make around $60k per year you only owe 12% on precious metals capital gains. If you make $600k+ per year then yes you will owe 28%.
>halfway there, spending another 20 bucks on gas, my back left tire blew out.
What does this have to do with silver?
>didnt have a spare
You make $600k per year and you can't afford a spare tire???

>biggest disappointment
The time cost mostly. Waiting a decade for a "measly" 1m which logically speaking isn't that bad but I wasted my youth and formative years looking at charts and having nothing to show for it. Any regular wagie has or will surpass me soon on top of having a more fulfilling social life network and career. I was always destined to be a sperg loser so I guess I can't be too mad.

61895534
what causes the next bull run? What is crypto's future?

We are past insitutional adoption, past regulation, past retail adoption (retail was burned hard by scamcoins), what causes the next run up?

I'm thinking we need to wait until retail forgets its past pain and we get another big stimulus check or something and they gamble it away on crypto. The only problem with this theory is that gambling has basically become legal now with gambling apps and the money might all flow into that instead.

61895549
>>61895130
No idea. I don't own shitcoins anymore outside of dust for the memes so don't care what happens to them, but at the bottom of every cycle the doomer narratives become the strongest, it always feels like it's genuinely over this time and we endure months/years of no price action, we're probably looking for even more pain once the multi-year recession for stocks comes. Recessions in stocks traditionally last 3.3 years (ath to ath, 11 months to bottom). But it's exactly that sinking feeling of despair in the pit of your stomach when even seasoned traders have lost all hope that wrecks normies and allows others to make money, why market cycles never stop occurring. But that's a tradfi thing so who knows maybe I'll baghold and kms in a decade.

The thing that bothers me the most is I am becoming old now (in my 30s) and weathering another market cycle means the prime of my life will already be pretty much over and I'd have to give up on finding a wife, having kids. I never made enough money to make up for the other shortcomings in my life, and the chickens are finally coming home to roost, as they say. On the bright side I can always wage with financial security which is nice, but the dreams I had when I was young have mostly vanished.

>>61895549

I already mentioned it you fucking retard. You can see the ledger amendment history that they have spent their own dev money and time developing, their acquisitions of Hidden Road, etc. their getting binance listing RLUSD on the XRPL, the fact the early team specifically coded the ledger to explicitly default to its use and to save several percentage points over Ripplenet alone by doing so, the fact that they locked the vast bulk of their corporate treasury up in timed release in it, the fact they fund and partner with multiple large banks to drive and encourage its use and adoption, and the fact the services they are building out literally optimize using it and offer counterparty-less feature that no other asset onchain can, and the fact that they already use it in their business. They literally legally can't use it in most contexts yet but with clarity their business can become much more efficient and as a result their core holding increases in value. There is LITERALLY no reason to argue they are not building for its use other than being butthurt that it is true and trying to repress reality like a faggot. They literally have Fednow service providers running XRPL nodes and big banks who are their largest outside investors issuing bonds that reward in XRP (who were celebrated recently in their specific crypto efforts by the financial regulator of Japan) and are partnering with DBS (biggest bank in Singapore (Switzerland of Asia) and Franklin Templeton (trillion plus dollars AUM) building out a repo market on the XRPL. They got ONDO issuing on the XRPL, one of the largest asset managers in Europe/England doing same while basically no one is getting headway in England, Societe General (one of biggest banks in Europe) expanding to include XRP for their euro stablecoin which can bridge to RLUSD using XRP, etc. Literally everything they do builds around corporately driving XRP's adoption, literally just fleshing out a business sweet around it.

You faggots were saying "no one is using RLUSD/they are using it on ETH" not even realizing how retarded it sounded saying no one was using a token that launched 1 year ago at the time (which has meteorically risen since) or having understood the obvious play of liquidity vacuuming from eth by establishing presence there and tapering into XRPL use which is exactly what they are doing. To you it not immediately having the marketcap of tether and deliberately sacrificing openness the existing liquidity base in a strategically retarded play is evidence of your own rightness. XRP began seeing tokenization basically immediately after the SEC appeal was dropped after it endured 5 fucking years of lawfare through Ethgate, during which eth was retardedly given the regulatory free pass by Clayton/Gensler and co. across this entire time being used to mint assets and establish itself with an artificial legal advantage baked in by the Epstein crowd literally because it could not compete technologically and is expensive and slow and fragmented with none of the same capacity for a universal protocol level compliance features or the broadness of MPT or escrow capability etc., having to cobble together standards across issuers and bake VERY centralized trust into the model and force us into L2 end service Hell. The CCP and JPM bought 95% of ETH in the ICO and tried to subvert actual defi and crypto and trojan horse us into digital slavery hell rather than allowing better technologies to win that can scale at L1 with built in compliance capabilities. Same reason they deliberately subverted bitcoin's build to be unusable as cash without scaling into shitty turbo-centralized L2s that are still too slow and expensive.

61897098
>>61895158
>>61897045
XRP is certainly having to play catch up for the literal sole reason that it was targeted for lawfare despite ETH very obviously being much closer to a traditional security than it with XRP not even having had an ICO, but claiming victory now is pretty fucking retarded and acting like people will just continue to use worse tech for no reason other than that they did before. This is like saying low cost highspeed rail transport or refrigerated semis would be rejected because horse and buggies and old school carrier automobiles exist and we can strap big engine onto them if we wanted and industry corporatists alligned to fight them early on. At one point the same argument would have been equally valid (completely retarded). Or saying banks will use bitcoin for high frequency payments. This is obviously retarded. We are in the late 90s in the internet technology analogy. We literally don't even have regulatory clarity for market structure yet. But it is all coming together now, many will be wiped out, the level regulatory playing field will change a LOT and it would have been fucking retarded to say Netscape won internet with unassailable moat because it was so dominant early (where is it now?). XRPL is being built out as the liquidity base of core institutional services, repo market between trillions AUM Franklin Templeton and DBS (largest bank in Singapore (Switzerland of Asia)), used by ONDO with the creator of ONDO launching a video detailing how RLUSD offramps and XRPL can be used to link Black Rock's BUIDL to other member participants' in ONDO (Wisdom Tree, Franklin Templeton etc.) other products etc. You are claiming to have won because you were allowed to tie your biggest challenger's arms who only needs a few innings to crush you, in the first two innings, and you STILL didn't even win vs. others in pic related. Lol XRPL payment volume has been going UP while ALL markedly of crypto has been going DOWN.

61897113
>>61895158
>>61897045
>>61897098
Further, XRP has proportionately outperformed any other asset over the last several years of launch in ETFs, and crushes every other crypto based one that launched alongside it, ESPECIALLY link, despite literally launching the day after the big downturn started months ago on MUCH smaller early issuers than other products.

>>61889273

its just so unfair i feel like crying

I knew a waitress 2 years ago working in a shitty diner that was finessing 3-4 boomers, I remember one time a boomer literally handed her a $3,000 check, no sexual favors or anything, just sweet talk, this chick was spending 5-10,000 dollars a month on clothes and was driving a brand new Jeep luxury model

61893631
>>61889354
I met a girl who was a friend of a friend of mine at a party when I was younger and she literally handed me a business card with her OF address on it. I didn't realize what it was at first but the second I read it I blurted out "What the fuck is wrong with you?" without thinking and she got super offended. I'm pretty sure I was the first person she handed it to that actually said anything negative about it by the way she reacted, which is very bizarre to me. It's kind of crazy how common this shit is.

>>61894538

61895453
>>61889270

>waaaah I'm unhappy because some people have it better

61895459

61895475

61895479
Ai will solve this and make chuds rich at the same time

61895520
why does OF cause so much psychic damage to anons? you know guys can make an OF too.

61895541
>>61889270
I guess those egirls are just that much smarter than you, because anyone with millions of dollars compared to a broke bitch must be smart.

61897746
fart

61899392
>>61889270
>>61889270
i dont even think about it, life is unfair, this is far from being one of the unfair things that matter.

61899395
>>61889298
i see car washes close down all the time, this is some boomer thinking.

61899410
For your OF to be successful, you have to be popular elsewhere first. OF is where you take your already dedicated audience for financial support in exchange for token nudes. Whores starting with OF and 0 exposure elsewhere, like camsites, will end up in the 90% majority who make nothing.

61899531
>>61889270
It is what it is, sometimes I get jealous at how much they're making.

At the same time, I don't want everything to be instantly given to me for little to no effort. Things which are effortless are often not gratifying. I like to struggle and overcome things. An RPG where you max out in five minutes is not satisfying or fun. Large payoffs after long periods of investment feel amazing. Putting in honest work for what you have builds a sense of accomplishment, self respect, and self esteem. People who become overnight millionaires from OF have no purpose in life. They have no struggle or real goals.

I took a philosophy class in college which posed the question of what one's life purpose is. For me, it really comes down to feeling good and enjoying myself. I think the most sustainable way to feel good and enjoy oneself is to repeatedly overcome meaningful obstacles for meaningful rewards.

One must imagine Sisyphus happy.
